summary.p: Greetings. Hopes that Euander remains in Kempten despite difficulties. Bucer has returned from Hesse and Saxony; further details are not yet known. Zwick has not yet seen Thomas [...] from Leuven, recommended by Leo [Jud]. That Michael [Back?] is doing well in Austria is also confirmed by [Balthasar von] Kuenring, but the spread of the Gospel is being hindered by the princes. Requests to share the news about Michael with Leo [Jud] as well.

div.p: I have nothing to write to you beyond greetings; however, these greetings are from all the brothers, especially Ambrosius, Konrad, and our consul Thomas. They all wish you well.

I heard some time ago that Euander would not remain in Kempten; I did not hear the reason until now from you, and I can easily believe that the good man is troubled there, yet I would not want the school in Kempten to be deprived of him.
Bucer has returned from Hesse and Saxony these days; we do not yet know what news he brings with him.
Leo recently recommended to me a certain Thomas from Leuven; but I have not seen the man anywhere.

I recently wrote about my Michael being well in Austria; in the meantime, Kuenring also writes the same. But what hope is there for the progress of the Gospel when kings and princes persecute it? But what am I saying, as if the kingdom of Christ does not advance despite the opposition of emperors!
But farewell with the whole household. January 27, 1539.
Greet Leo in many ways in my name and inform him of what I wrote here about Michael.
To Lord Heinrich Bullinger, dearest of brothers.
